Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Computational Design of Generic Underwater Adhesives based on Conjugating DOPA-Containing Polymers and Amyloid-Forming Peptides

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
#1512058
Hall, Carol K.


Generic adhesives capable of sticking to surfaces in water or in high moisture conditions are in demand for applications ranging from marine coatings to medical devices to underwater sensors. One way to develop such adhesives is to learn from nature. Analysis of the adhesive substances employed by mussels, barnacles, algae and yeasts reveals two common factors that seem to contribute to their ability to attach to a wide range of surfaces in water: 3, 4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) and amyloid-forming peptides. A new class of generic underwater adhesives will be developed by combining synthetic DOPA-containing polymers and amyloid-forming peptides. Synthetic materials will be deployed, instead of the naturally-occurring proteins favored by other investigators, because they should be easier to tailor and to produce in large scale. A computationally-driven program of research will be conducted to better the understanding of how the peptide sequences and DOPA-containing polymers in a peptide-polymer conjugate can be engineered to function synergistically, thereby providing superior adhesion to surfaces in water.

Atomistic and coarse-grained molecular simulations will be used to develop a set of molecular-level principles that can guide the design of DOPA-peptide conjugates. Such materials, which are inspired by naturally-occurring materials including mussels and barnacles, are expected to form the basis of a new generation of underwater adhesives capable of binding to a wide range of surfaces. Five short peptide sequences taken from the amyloid forming regions of the glues employed by yeast cells have been identified as good starting sequences. Four surfaces will be considered: graphite, graphite coated with OH groups, gold, and titanium oxide. The specific aims of this project are to: 1) identify the roles played by each amino-acid residue on naturally-derived peptides in forming amyloid structure; 2) develop a set of principles for designing polymer-peptide conjugates such that the peptides can form amyloid structures without associating with the polymers; and 3) investigate the behavior of conjugates near four model surfaces to assess their ability to attach nonspecifically in water. The DOPA-peptide conjugates that show the most promise will be synthesized by an experimentalist collaborator, and tested to see if they form amyloid structures and if they adhere strongly to the four surfaces.

The proposed project could impact research in the areas of interfacial phenomena, sensing, coating, surface modification and drug delivery where material adherence to surfaces in water is critical. The computational design strategy, which draws initial inspiration from natural products and then iterates back and forth between atomistic and coarse-grained simulations to home in on promising molecular architectures, could point the way to the systematic design and discovery of other new materials that are tailored for specific applications. In addition to training a Ph.D. student, research and education will be fostered by: (1) using the computational design of the new materials as the basis for examples developed for the PI's undergraduate chemical engineering thermodynamics course, (2) creating a power-point presentation describing the basics of computational materials design and distributing via the web, and (3) making a video presentation targeted for general audiences that shows how molecular-level computer simulation can be used to design materials with special functionality. The PI will continue her considerable, but informal, nationwide activities to broaden the opportunities for women in STEM fields and will introduce a brown bag lunch series for women graduate students and postdocs in her department at NCSU to discuss topics of common interest.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

An atomistic modeling investigation of 3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) and an amyloid-forming peptide was conducted with the goal of better understanding their behavior in underwater conditions in the context of adhesion. Generic adhesives capable of sticking to a variety of surfaces in water and high moisture conditions are in demand for many applications, including marine coatings, medical devices, and underwater sensors. However, typical industrial glues lose their adhesive strength in water as they are generally designed for dry use. Analysis of the natural adhesive substances employed by aquatic organisms such as mussels, barnacles, bacteria, and yeasts has revealed two potentially key components in their ability to attach to a large range of surfaces: DOPA and functional amyloid nanostructures. The proposed solution is to design generic underwater adhesives that leverage the abilities of DOPA and amyloid structures by conjugating a DOPA-containing chain to an amyloid-forming peptide.

Intellectual Merit:

(1)   Refinement of a simulation force field for DOPA: Model molecular energy parameters for DOPA molecules in the CHARMM36 force field were developed and refined. The parameters were obtained through a trial-and-error process that produced the best match between simulation and experimental values of the DOPA-in-water solubility parameter and the DOPA dipole moment. These refined force field parameters allow explicit-solvent atomistic simulations of DOPA molecules with other biological molecules (such as an amyloid-forming peptide).  

(2)   Investigation of the behavior of DOPA molecules in underwater conditions: Atomistic simulations of the DOPA molecules in water solutions at standard conditions and various DOPA concentrations revealed that there is unlikely to be significant clustering between DOPA molecules in water, leaving them free to adsorb to nearby surfaces. See Figure 1. 

(3)    DOPA molecule adsorption on a model underwater surface: Knowledge of the interactions between DOPA molecules, water, and surfaces is essential in the design of novel DOPA-based molecules that can adhere to multiple types of underwater surfaces. An aqueous system of DOPA molecules on a silica slab was simulated to examine: (a) the collective behavior of the molecules as they approach the surface, and (b) the DOPA-DOPA and DOPA-surface interactions during adhesion. See Figure 2. 

(4)   Design of a peptide-based DOPA chain molecule: simulations in underwater conditions: A DOPA- containing chain molecule was designed to have a peptide backbone with 3 DOPA groups alternating with 3 glycines. Simulations of this DOPA-containing chain showed that the DOPA groups on the chains do not fold in on themselves, leaving them free to adhere to nearby surfaces. See Figure 3. 

(5)   DOPA-amyloid conjugates in underwater conditions: The idea behind the design of new underwater adhesives is to conjugate a DOPA-containing “polymer” chain to an amyloid-forming peptide, thereby leveraging the adhesive capabilities of the two components. An initial design for a generic underwater adhesive involve was constructed in which the DOPA-containing chain (alternating DOPA and glycine) was conjugated to KLVFFAE, a known amyloid-forming peptide (KLVFFAE). A single DOPA-amyloid conjugate molecule was simulated in water to assess potential interactions between the assorted groups along the chain. See Figure 4.  A secondary simulation of  a tyrosine-amyloid analogue (with tyrosine in place of DOPA) in water was also performed to serve as a point of reference for the design. These results contribute to our understanding of how DOPA (or DOPA-like groups such as tyrosine) interact with the amyloid-forming peptide prior to contact with a surface.

Broader Impact:

(1) This project has trained 1 female graduate student and 1 postdoctoral associate. The graduate student recently won the N. C. State Chemical Engineering Department’s 2018 Praxair Award for Outstanding Teaching assistant. The postdoctoral associate has obtained a faculty position at the University of Kentucky

(2) This research furthers our understanding of DOPA-containing systems in water, and how DOPA interacts with water, different amino acids, and a surface. Our results provide insight into mechanisms by which naturally-occurring adhesives work and strategies to design new materials based on them.

(3) The preliminary results on the underwater adhesive project  have been presented at university symposia; several publications are in preparation. Five papers on related work have been published, and one has been accepted, and one is in the revision stage.
